entry.title: Protractor test suites as Promises
entry.summary:
In this article I will demonstrate you another way how to write effective and re-usables tests using Protractor. In general this post can be treated as smooth continuation of my previous article about DRY principles with Protractor e2e testing framework. But this time I will show you how to use Promises as more effective way of dealing with results of evalutions of test suites and how to combine test suites togther.

As of scenario for our test let's again assume that our imaginary web application that we want to test has a login functionality. In other words each test that we want to implement should pass authorization first.

Let's implement this.

For this purpose I will use the same "login suite" as in previous article:

describe('login suite', function() {
    var protractor;
    var loginButton = element(by.css('#submitButton')).click();

    beforeEach(function(){
        protractor = protractor.getInstance();
    });

    afterEach(function(){
        //e.g. we need to have "clean" state after execution of each test - no auth cookies 
        protractor.manage().deleteAllCookies();
    });

    it('can get content of protected page1', function() {
        protractor.get('/login-protected-page-1/');

        element(by.model('model.login')).sendKeys('yourlogin');
        element(by.input('model.password')).sendKeys('yourpassword');

        loginButton.click().then(function() {
            //the ONLY important part of your test
            var elems = element.all(by.repeater('d in data'));
            expect(elems.count()).toBe(30);
        }); 
    });

    it('can get content of protected page2', function() {
        protractor.get('/login-protected-page-2/');

        element(by.model('model.login')).sendKeys('yourlogin');
        element(by.input('model.password')).sendKeys('yourpassword');

        loginButton.click().then(function() {
            //the ONLY important part of your test
            var elems = element.all(by.repeater('d in data'));
            expect(elems.count()).toBe(15);
        }); 
    });
});

Ok. Nothing special here. Now let's have a look how we could improve this code in order to use login in other test suites without loosing in readability and keeping our code clean and DRY.

This time we will apply power of Promises.

Let's re-write first "Login part" (login_test.js):

var loginSuite = function(suiteName, specName, url) {
    var defer = protractor.promise.defer();

    describe(suiteName, function() {
        var prot = protractor.getInstance();

        afterEach(function() {
            protractor.manage().deleteAllCookies();
        });

        it(specName, function() {
            prot.get(url);
            element(by.model('model.username')).sendKeys('yourlogin');
            element(by.model('model.password')).sendKeys('yourpassword');
            element(by.id('loginButton')).click().then(defer.fulfill, defer.reject);
        });
    });

    return defer.promise;
};

Main difference here from original code is that we return Promise object which will be fullfilled on login form submission event.

And now time to re-write "assertion part" of our original test suite:

var loginSuite = require('./login_test.js');

loginSuite('suite for page1', 'can get content of protected page1', '/login-protected-page-1/')
    .then(
        function() {
            var elems = element.all(by.repeater('d in data'));
            expect(elems.count()).toBe(30);
        }
    );

loginSuite('suite for page2', 'can get content of protected page2', '/login-protected-page-2/')
    .then(
        function() {
            var elems = element.all(by.repeater('d in data'));
            expect(elems.count()).toBe(15);
        }
    );

That's was it.

In conclusion I would say that using Promises in test suites in favor of callbacks in Protractor looks more natural (in fact whole Protractor API utilize promises). Especially in situations when you will start to implement more complex scenarious where one suites will rely on multiple other suites. This would definitely make debugging and implementation much more easier.

Some usefull links:

  • e2e testing with Protractor
  • Protractor API
  • Javascript Promises

entry.title: DRY principles with Protractor e2e testing framework
entry.summary:
This article describes concepts of DRY(Don't repeat yourself) principle which can be applied when writing e2e tests for AngularJS application.

First of all writing e2e tests is very straitforward task thats why developers often trying to implement them without thinking of code reuse and following main principle of "copy-past". To some point it could work untill certain part of your appplication would be re-implemented and will have new behaviour.

Enough lyrics. Lets look at very common use case. So, lets say your application has a login functionality and each of your tests will rely on the fact that you will be logged-in and will able to access login-protected areas.

Here is one possible implementation:

describe('login suite', function() {
    var protractor;
    var loginButton = element(by.css('#submitButton')).click();

    beforeEach(function(){
        protractor = protractor.getInstance();
    });

    afterEach(function(){
        //e.g. we need to have "clean" state after execution of each test - no auth cookies 
        protractor.manage().deleteAllCookies();
    });

    it('can get content of protected page1', function() {
        protractor.get('/login-protected-page-1/');

        element(by.model('model.login')).sendKeys('yourlogin');
        element(by.input('model.password')).sendKeys('yourpassword');

        loginButton.click().then(function() {
            //the ONLY important part of your test
            var elems = element.all(by.repeater('d in data'));
            expect(elems.count()).toBe(30);
        }); 
    });

    it('can get content of protected page2', function() {
        protractor.get('/login-protected-page-2/');

        element(by.model('model.login')).sendKeys('yourlogin');
        element(by.input('model.password')).sendKeys('yourpassword');

        loginButton.click().then(function() {
            //the ONLY important part of your test
            var elems = element.all(by.repeater('d in data'));
            expect(elems.count()).toBe(15);
        }); 
    });
});

Now lets imagine that you have tons of parts in your web application that relies on login. Of course you can put all test suites just in one file and use nice approach of nested suites ("describe"). But in the end you will get unmaintainable file with thousands lines ugly spaghetti code.

What could help us here. Modularity and de-coupling or better divide and conquer principle.

So lets get started. Lets first try to make login part reusable (login_test.js).

module.exports = function(testName, loginProtectedUrl, testFn) {
    describe('common login suite', function() {
        var protractor;
        var loginButton = element(by.css('#submitButton')).click();

        beforeEach(function(){
            protractor = protractor.getInstance();
        });

        afterEach(function(){
            protractor.manage().deleteAllCookies();
        });

        it(testName, function() {
            protractor.get(loginProtectedUrl);

            element(by.model('model.login')).sendKeys('yourlogin');
            element(by.input('model.password')).sendKeys('yourpassword');

            loginButton.click().then(function() {
                //call of actual test. And pass instance of protractor
                testFn(protractor);
            }); 
        });
    });
}

And now lets re-write original e2e tests:

var loginSuite = require('./login_test.js');

loginSuite('can get content of protected page1', '/login-protected-page-1/', function(protractorInstance) {
    var elems = element.all(by.repeater('d in data'));
    expect(elems.count()).toBe(30);
});

loginSuite('can get content of protected page2', '/login-protected-page-1/', function(protractorInstance) {
    var elems = element.all(by.repeater('d in data'));
    expect(elems.count()).toBe(15);
});

That's pretty much of it. As a little bonus as you can see I pass back protractorInstance to callback function in order to have flexibility when you will need to have access to other Protactor functions.

Cheers!

Some usefull links:

  • Jasmine
  • Protractor
  • e2e testing with Protractor
  • Protractor API

entry.title: Multi language handling in Solr
entry.summary:
If you are building full-text search application for your website on top of Apache Solr once you will definitly face the problem on how to handle multiple language. There are at least 2 possibilities how to do it and here I will describe you both of them with possible bottlnecks you might have and solutions to upcoming problems.

1. Multicore approach

Perhaps most popular and well discribed is multicore approach. It is really easy to setup and start using it almost immidiatly if you already have configured one core (schema.xml and solrconfig.xml). You just need to dublicate existing core as many times as many languages you have. Than upon reading/writing select proper core depending on incoming language. That is all the magick. By the way, demo example of multicore solr configuration is included in each downloadable solr package by this path solr-4.X.X/example/multicore

2. Single core approach with language separation by document language field

This approach assume that you will use one core for storing all document languages and differentiate them by storing additional information about language inside solr document (e.g. language, iso code). This requires a bit more configuration therefore I will demonstrate you key changes that you will have to make to your solr schema and solrconfig files.

Lets assume we have 2 languages English and German.

1. Add configuration of language specific field types to schema.xml

<!-- fieldType for each language (default, en, de) -->
<fieldType name="text" class="solr.TextField" />
<fieldType name="text_en" class="solr.TextField" />
<fieldType name="text_de" class="solr.TextField" />

Here can be added additional information about language specific stopwords, synonyms and etc.

2. Add fields that might contain language specific data (e.g. title, desciption)

<!-- configuration of fields in schema.xml for each language (default, en, de) -->
<field name="title" type="text" indexed="true"  stored="true" />
<field name="title_en" type="text_en" indexed="true" stored="true" />
<field name="title_de" type="text_de" indexed="true" stored="true" />

3. If you use dynamicField definition in your schema which might also be language specific also do not forget to describe it 

<dynamicField name="*_s" type="string" indexed="true" stored="true" />
<dynamicField name="*_s_en" type="string" indexed="true" stored="true" />
<dynamicField name="*_s_de" type="string" indexed="true" stored="true" />

4. Add field which will store information about language and iso code if necessary

<field name="language" type="string"  indexed="true" stored="true" />
<field name="iso_code" type="string"  indexed="true" stored="true" />

Upon writing to Solr do not forget to fill language and/or iso_code field as long as always fill default language specific fields (without prefix) and language specific fields with prefix. So in the end depending on Solr document language you will have something like:

<!-- for english document -->
<str name="title">some english title</str>
<str name="title_en">some english title</str>
<str name="language">en</str>
<str name="iso_code">en-us</str>

and on opposite side for German document

<!-- for german document -->
<str name="title">einige deutsch titel</str>
<str name="title_de">einige deutsch titel</str>
<str name="language">de</str>
<str name="iso_code">de-de</str>

Thats basically all.

Some additional hints for those who are using Solr SpellCheckComponent.

Someone maybe a bit disappointed to see German suggestion in English search and other way around. However I might say sometimes it could be pretty funny. But nevertheless to make SpellCheckComponent to function properly again you need to add some addtional configuration to your SpellCheckComponent in solrconfig.xml:

1. You need to add spellchecker for each language (in our case English and German)

<searchComponent name="spellcheck" class="solr.SpellCheckComponent">
    <str name="queryAnalyzerFieldType">textSpell</str>
    <lst name="spellchecker">
        <str name="name">default</str>
        <str name="field">spell</str>
        <str name="buildOnOptimize">true</str>
        <str name="buildOnCommit">true</str>
        <str name="spellcheckIndexDir">./spellchecker</str>
    </lst>
    <lst name="spellchecker">
        <str name="name">spell_en</str>
        <str name="field">spell_en</str>
        <str name="buildOnOptimize">true</str>
        <str name="buildOnCommit">true</str>
        <str name="spellcheckIndexDir">./spellchecker_en</str>
    </lst>
    <lst name="spellchecker">
        <str name="name">spell_de</str>
        <str name="field">spell_de</str>
        <str name="buildOnOptimize">true</str>
        <str name="buildOnCommit">true</str>
        <str name="spellcheckIndexDir">./spellchecker_de</str>
    </lst>
</searchComponent>

2. Register additional spellchecker dictionaries in requestHandler

<requestHandler name="/spellCheckCompRH" class="solr.SearchHandler" lazy="true">
    <lst name="defaults">
        <str name="spellcheck.dictionary">default</str>
        <str name="spellcheck.dictionary">spell_en</str>
        <str name="spellcheck.dictionary">spell_de</str>
        <str name="spellcheck.count">1</str>
    </lst>
    <arr name="last-components">
        <str>spellcheck</str>
    </arr>
</requestHandler>

3. Add prefixed spell fields for each language to solr schema.xml

<field name="spell" type="solr.TextField" indexed="true" stored="false" multiValued="true" />
<field name="spell_en" type="solr.TextField" indexed="true" stored="false" multiValued="true" />
<field name="spell_de" type="solr.TextField" indexed="true" stored="false" multiValued="true" />

4. In your application which generates Solr queries and communicatates to Solr server add &spellcheck.dictionary=spell_ param to search query depending on language. Please note that if you will note provide this parameter default spellchecker will be used which contain wrong index!!!*

Conclusion

Multicore approach

  • Very easy and straightforward way to start playing with. Requires almost ZERO configuration efforts and do not require deep understanding of Solr configuration options;
  • However you migh already guess that this approach has at least one main disadvantage which is maintanance and it will increase proportionally to the amout of languages you will have to deal with;

Single core approach with language separation by document language field

  • Requires a bit more configuration and understanding of Solr in the beginning;
  • Easy to maintain/deploy;

In my opinion both approaches fit nicely to any number of languages, however I would preferably use second one due to maintainance costs reasons.

entry.title: AngularJS in production - part 3
entry.summary:
This is the third part of "AngularJS in production" series. Here I will cover topics related to minification of your source code, continuous integration and finally deployment of your application.

Source code minification

As you remember from part 1 and part 2 from this series we utilize RequireJS in our application. Luckily for us RequireJS is shipped with an optimization tool which:

  • Combines related scripts together into build layers and minifies them via UglifyJS;
  • Optimizes CSS by inlining CSS files referenced by @import and removing comments.

There are multiple options how to run optimizer:

  • Node;
  • Java with Rhino;
  • directly in browser;

We will use Node. And as stated in official RequireJS optimization docs node is the preferred execution environment and the optimizer runs much faster with Node.

What is really awesome about optimizer is that we can reuse existing RequireJS configuration file for minification and merge all our JS source files into one single file.

Lets look how our configuration file can look like concidering our code structure from part 1 of this series (buildwidgetapp.js)

({
    baseUrl: ".",
    paths: {
        requireLib: "vendors/require/require"
    },
    mainConfigFile: "widgetapp.js",
    name: "widgetapp",
    out: "widgets.js"
})

The most import option here is mainConfigFile which defines RequireJS configuration file we should use. Information about all possible configuration params you can read here.

Lets call an optimizer from command line:

./node_modules/requirejs/bin/r.js -o buildwidgetapp.js include=requireLib
  • buildwidgetapp.js - is path to our configuration file;
  • include=requireLib - tells optimizer to include RequireJS library on top of the compressed file (before any other module of the application) cause all apllication is relies on existence of RequireJS file.

Continuous integration with Jenkins

Before creation of integration jobs lets remember how our Karma configuration file(karma.conf.js) look like:

module.exports = function(config) {
    config.set({
        frameworks: ['jasmine', 'requirejs'], //js testing fromework to use
        //appliction code structure
        files: [
            {pattern:'vendors/angular-1.0.7/angular.js', included: false},
            {pattern:'vendors/angular-1.0.7/angular-resource.js', included: false},
            {pattern:'vendors/angular-1.0.7/angular-mocks.js', included: false},
            {pattern:'vendors/jquery/jquery-1.10.2.js', included: false},
            {pattern:'widgetapp/*.js', included: false},
            {pattern:'widgetapp/controllers/*.js', included: false},
            {pattern:'widgetapp/models/*.js', included: false},
            {pattern:'widgetapp/tests/unit/*test.js', included: false},
            'widgetapp/tests/main.js'
        ],
        // list of files to exclude
        exclude: [
            'widgetapp/bootstrap.js'
        ],
        // test results reporter to use
        reporters: ['junit'],
        port: 9876,
        colors: true,
        //log level
        logLevel: config.LOG_ERROR || config.LOG_WARN || config.LOG_INFO || config.LOG_DEBUG,
        autoWatch: false,
        browsers: ['PhantomJS'], //in which browser to test
        captureTimeout: 60000,
        // if true, it capture browsers, run tests and exit. CI mode
        singleRun: true,
        //Test report XML
        junitReporter: {
            outputFile: 'test-results.xml'
        }
    })
}

Here we are only interested in two configuration options "reporters" and "junitReporter" which actually define which test reporter to use and in which file generate output.

Than in Jenkins, start a new job for Angular/Karma with the basic settings (Name, description, parameters, source code repo to pull from, etc.) and in "Execute shell" shell setting add following code:

cd path/to/your/AppRoot/
npm install 
./node_modules/karma/bin/karma start
./node_modules/requirejs/bin/r.js -o buildwidgetapp.js include=requireLib

Define absolute path to your "test-results.xml" in Publish JUnit test result report setting.

path/to/your/AppRoot/test-results.xml

As you already might guess the result of this Jenkins job would be our test report in Jenkins artifacts folder and our minified "widgets.js" file which we could include easily add to HTML and deploy our application to the users.

That's all for now folks.

entry.title: AngularJS in production - part 2
entry.summary:
This is second part from "AngularJS in production" series. In this part I will talk about test runner, testing framework and writing unit tests in AngularJS application.

If you have have never heard about Karma it is really good time to start digg it now. In short: Karma is "Spectacular Test Runner for JavaScript" (as stated on website). It is build to make life of developers easy especially when it comes to testing JS applications. It comes with all batteries included like: easy install via NPM, bunch of popular testing frameworks (Jasmine, QUnit, Mocha), testing on real devices + headless testing with PhantomJS, easy debugging and simple continuous intergration.

First lets create NPM package configuration file in our AppRoot (package.json):

{
    "name": "demo-angular-js-app",
    "version": "0.0.1",
    "description": "Demo package configuration",
    "author": {
        "name": "Pavlo Bogomolenko"
    },
    "dependencies": {
        "karma":"0.10.*",
        "karma-jasmine":"*",
        "karma-junit-reporter": "~0.1",
        "requirejs":"2.1.*"
    },
    "engines": {
        "node": "~0.10.15"
    },
    "licenses": [
    {
        "type": "GPL"
    }
    ]
}

Now lets install all described packages:

npm install

In order to work properly with your application Karma should know about you application structure. So let's quickly return to our code structure from part 1.

AppRoot
 vendors
  ...
 widgetapp
  controllers
  ...
  models
  ...
  tests
      main.js
      unit
          controllers.test.js
          models.test.js
          modules.test.js
          routes.test.js
 buildwidgetapp.js
 karma.conf.js
 package.json
 widgetapp.js

Lets define Karma configuration file(karma.conf.js):

module.exports = function(config) {
    config.set({
        frameworks: ['jasmine', 'requirejs'], //js testing fromework to use
        //appliction code structure
        files: [
            {pattern:'vendors/angular-1.0.7/angular.js', included: false},
            {pattern:'vendors/angular-1.0.7/angular-resource.js', included: false},
            {pattern:'vendors/angular-1.0.7/angular-mocks.js', included: false},
            {pattern:'vendors/jquery/jquery-1.10.2.js', included: false},
            {pattern:'widgetapp/*.js', included: false},
            {pattern:'widgetapp/controllers/*.js', included: false},
            {pattern:'widgetapp/models/*.js', included: false},
            {pattern:'widgetapp/tests/unit/*test.js', included: false},
            'widgetapp/tests/main.js'
        ],
        // list of files to exclude
        exclude: [
            'widgetapp/bootstrap.js'
        ],
        // test results reporter to use
        reporters: ['junit'],
        port: 9876,
        colors: true,
        //log level
        logLevel: config.LOG_ERROR || config.LOG_WARN || config.LOG_INFO || config.LOG_DEBUG,
        autoWatch: false,
        browsers: ['PhantomJS'], //in which browser to test
        captureTimeout: 60000,
        // if true, it capture browsers, run tests and exit. CI mode
        singleRun: true,
        junitReporter: {
            outputFile: 'test-results.xml'
        }
    })
}

Configuration should look pretty straightforward. More information about properties and possible options you can always find in official documentation.

What is really important in our case is that we use RequireJS to load all our modules asynchronously and keep dependencies clear. Therefore we need RequireJS configuration file for loading tests as well and ideally we should be able to reuse existing RequireJS configuration file from part 1 of this series.

That's what we will actually do next and luckily Karma support RequireJS natively with few additinal properties.

Now lets create RequireJS configuration for our test suits (AppRoot/tests/main.js):

//Now we can tell Require.js to load our tests, which must be done asynchronously
// as dependencies must be fetched before the tests are run..
var tests = [];
for (var file in window.__karma__.files) {
    if (window.__karma__.files.hasOwnProperty(file)) {
        if (/test\.js$/.test(file)) {
            console.log('Loading test suit: ' + file);
            tests.push(file);
        }
    }
}

//require config for tests. Basically we will reuse this section from (widgetapp.js)
//with few additional options
requirejs.config({
    //By default load any module from base
    baseUrl: '/base',
    //configure dependencies
    shim: {
        angular: {exports: 'angular'},
        ngResource: {
            deps: ['angular'],
            exports: 'angular'
        },
        mock: {
            deps: ['angular'],
            exports: 'angular.mock'
        },
        jq: {'exports' : 'jQuery'}
    },
    //configure additional paths from where to load modules 
    paths: {
        angular: 'vendors/angular-1.0.7/angular',
        ngResource: 'vendors/angular-1.0.7/angular-resource',
        mock: 'vendors/angular-1.0.7/angular-mocks',
        jq: 'vendors/jquery/jquery-1.10.2'
    },
    // ask Require.js to load these files (all our tests - see above)
    deps: tests,
    // start test run, once Require.js is done
    callback: window.__karma__.start
});

We will use Jasmine as testing framework which is quite obvious choice due to clean and self-descriptive syntax and in fact whole AngularJS code base is covered with it.

Due to the fact that all unit tests are application specific lets define one "general" (of course even here we will rely on existence of certain modules) which will simply check if all our modules has been loaded (tests/unit/modules.test.js):

//define(['angular', 'jq', 'mock', 'widgetapp/app'],
    function(angular, jq, mock, App) {
        describe('Testing WidgetApp module', function() {
            var module;
            beforeEach(function() {
                $('body').append('<div id="widget">{{widgetData}}</div>');
                var conf = {"end_point_url":""};
                var app = new App($('#widget'), conf);

                module = angular.module('Widgetapp');
            });

            it("should be registered", function() {
                expect(module).not.toBeUndefined();
            });

            describe("Dependencies:", function() {
                var deps;
                var hasModule = function(m) {
                    return deps.indexOf(m) >= 0;
                };

                beforeEach(function() {
                    deps = module.value('appName').requires;
                });

                it("should have Controllers as a dependency", function() {
                    expect(hasModule('Controllers')).toEqual(true);
                });
            });
        });
    }
);

Now lets run Karma:

/node_modules/karma/bin/karma start

And if everything run smoothely you could see something like in your command line:

PhantomJS 1.9.2 (Linux): Executed 2 of 2 SUCCESS (0.276 secs / 0.024 secs)

If you will have something different probably you messed soemthing with your configuration and/or your tests has failed.

In general Unit testing and especially testing AngularJS topics are far larger than I described here and goes beyond this article but in general you should now able to explore new horizons by yourself and be able to setup testing environment easily.

In the part 3 of this series I would finally share you information about Continious integration of AngularJS application and cover some aspects of deployment process.

Stay tuned.

entry.title: AngularJS in production - part 1
entry.summary:
In this article I would like to share you my production experience with AngularJS based applications. I will try to cover topics related to development process, testing and integrtion as well as some hints on how to optimize your AngularJS application.

In this part I would like to start with code structure and dependencies management which are most important things you have to think about before implementation.

So lets start.

Code structure

This is how your code structure might look like:

AppRoot
 vendors
  angular-1.0.7
  jquery
   jquery-1.10.2.js
  require
      require.js
 widgetapp
  app.js
  bootstrap.js
  controllers
   widget.js
  data
   config.json
   sample.json
  models
   urlbuilder.js
  services
   configurationresource.js
  tests
      main.js
      unit
          controllers.test.js
          models.test.js
          modules.test.js
          routes.test.js
 buildwidgetapp.js
 karma.conf.js
 package.json
 widgetapp.js

In general you can use whatever structure you like just keep in mind that it should be "self speakable" and clear.

Dependencies management

In addition to well-orginized code structure we need an easy way to load all modules and keep an eye on module/external libraries dependencies. Likely AngularJS is build to support Asynchronous Module Definition and therefore we would you use RequireJS to achive this.

So lets define RequireJS configuration file(widgetapp.js):

requirejs.config({
        //By default load any module from js path
        baseUrl: 'path/to/your/application/AppRoot',
        //configure dependencies
        shim: {
                angular: {exports: 'angular'},
                ngResource: {
                        deps: ['angular'],
                        exports: 'angular'
                },
                jq: {'exports' : 'jQuery'}
        },
        //configure additional paths from where to load modules
        paths: {
                angular: 'vendors/angular-1.0.7/angular',
                ngResource: 'vendors/angular-1.0.7/angular-resource',
                //ngSanitize: 'vendors/angular-1.0.7/angular-sanitize',
                jq: 'vendors/jquery/jquery-1.10.2'
        }
});

//init application
require(['widgetapp/bootstrap'], function() {});

And here are our demo bootstrap file(widgetapp/bootstrap.js):

define('widgetapp/bootstrap',
        ['angular', 'jq', 'widgetapp/services/configurationresource', 'widgetapp/app'],
        function(angular, jq, w, App) {
            //application initialization goes here
        }
);

Success. At this point you already have working structrure. Now it is time to setup test runner, select testing framework and start writing your tests. This part I will try to cover in part 2.
